questions.question: If you see an image named 'python:3.9-alpine', what does 'alpine' represent?

options.text: A variant of the image based on a tiny Linux distribution
The name of the registry server

questions.explanation: Alpine is a minimal Linux distribution often used as a base for Docker images to keep them small (usually under 5MB for the OS layer).

questions.question: What is the default tag used by Docker if you don't specify one?
questions.explanation: If no tag is provided in a command (like pull or run), Docker automatically appends ':latest'.

questions.question: Which command is used to delete a Docker image from your local machine?
questions.explanation: 'docker rm' is for containers. 'docker rmi' (remove image) is specifically for deleting images.

questions.question: Why does Docker often say 'Already exists' when you are pulling a new image?

options.text: Because Docker images are made of layers, and you already have some of those layers locally
Because Docker doesn't support multiple versions

questions.explanation: Docker images are composed of multiple read-only layers. If different images share the same parent layer (like a specific Ubuntu base), Docker is smart enough to download it only once.
